result.title: Objective
result.description: Objective: To expand and strengthen the terrestrial PA system in the Philippines by developing new PA models and building capacity for effective management of the system

indicator.title: Indicator 1

baseline.comment:
59 terrestrial PAs covering 2.6 million hectares
New PAs are established only through the NIPAS process
No program for accelerated expansion of terrestrial PAs to cover new conservation areas

target.comment:
Additional 9 terrestrial PAs covering 400,000 hectares, bringing the total area of KBA under protection to 3 million hectares
At least three new governance types IP, LGU and local community managed conservation areas recognized by Executive fiat as part of national PA system
Program for accelerated expansion of terrestrial PA system to include new conservation areas within KBAs developed and ready for implementation

actual.comment:
Partially Achieved. Since Project start, a total of 46 PAs/LCAs and ICCAs covering 400,724 hectares of KBAs have been added to the countrys protected area system:
3 PAs covering 174,549 hectares
26 LCAs from NewCAPP covering 80,163 hectares
10 ICCAs from NewCAPP covering 68,179 hectares; 3 ICCAs registered at UNEP/WCMC
1 LCA in BPP site (Mt. Hamiguitan) - 3,784 hectares
5 ICCAs recognized through FPE, and PTFCF covering 73,002 hectares
1 ICCA registered at UNEP/WCMC from non NewCAPP sites - 1,047 hectares
This brings to 3,007,009 hectares, the total area of KBAs under protection.
The Senate has passed on Second Reading, the Enhanced NIPAS Bill seeking to legislate 97 PAs, and strengthen NIPAS provisions, including recognition of ICCAs within PAs. Of these, 92 are existing PAs with Presidential Proclamations, while 5 are new PAs that will form part of the national PA estate. Once approved, the Bill will strengthen the legal status of these nationally legislated PAs under the NIPAS. In all, these 97 PAs cover 2,674,830.68 hectares and an additional of 179, 439.60 hectares of buffer zones in all; 59 are within KBA.
Based on various presentations and advocacies, an additional 33 LGUs and 209 IP organizations have expressed interest to establish LCAs and document their ICCAs, respectively.
GIZ-PAME is supporting LCAs and ICCAs in the establishment of 100 new sites (terrestrial and marine PAs) in KBAs.
Based on NewCAPPs lessons and experiences, a medium sized GEF proposal has been developed to strengthen policy and capacities for ICCA recognition in the Philippines, to cover an additional 10 sites with estimated total coverage of 118,000 hectares
NewCAPP spearheaded the preparation of a National PA System Master Plan that will guide the expansion of the Philippines PA estate, based on the following criteria: (i) representativeness, comprehensiveness, and balance; (ii) adequacy; (iii) coherence and complementarity; (iv) consistency; and (v) cost effectiveness, efficiency and equity. The Plan recognizes LCAs, ICCAs and other effective area based conservation measures (OECMs) as part of the National PA System.
Only two new modalities were developed under the Project. The Project was not able to find a workable model on community-managed CA. In lieu of this, the Project tried to investigate the viability of a privately-managed CA. But this did not progress as well. But the 2 models (LCA and ICCA) proved to be very viable option in expanding the protected area system.
On the policy, while no executive fiat was secured to support LCA and ICCA, the project was able to influence Environment Management Bureau (EMB) to consider these as environmentally critical areas compelling other development activities such as mining to undertake full-blown impact assessment. The project was also able to draft a number of supportive policies and turned over to BMB. One of which was the ICCA Bill which was passed in the Committee level in both houses of Congress.
Both Congress and Senate have approved at Committee level, the Draft ICCA Bill. KBAs, LCAs and ancestral domain lands are now considered as environmentally critical areas (ECAs) per Memorandum Circular of the Environmental Management Bureau on the Revised Procedures for the Philippines EIA System.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Habitat range of 109 globally threatened species in 9 pilot sites protected

baseline.comment: Expected to decrease by at least 10% per year

target.comment: Increase by 200%

actual.comment:
Achieved. The habitat of 186 globally threatened in 14 project sites within 10 KBAs are now protected by the local government units, local and indigenous cultural communities through the establishments of 24 LCAs and recognition of 10 ICCAs. Below is the summary:
- 27 critically endangered (1 reptilia, 6 aves, 1 mamalia, 19 magnoliopsida)
- 34 endangered (3 amphibia, 15 aves, 4 mamalia, 11 magnoliopsida, 1 coniferopsida)
- 125 vulnerable (21 amphibia, 8 reptilia, 39 aves, 9 mamalia, 48 magnoliopsida)
- 1threatened species (1 aves Hypothymis helenae )
However, please take note that during the biodiversity assessment and resource inventory conducted in the project sites, a total of 309 species were recorded and have not been classified yet but are deemed locally important/significant. The breakdown of these species are as follow:
- 12 amphibia
- 50 reptilia
- 82 aves
- 25 mamalia
- 136 magnoliopsida
- 4 coniferopsida
These data may be taken as baseline information and partial list of species. A more comprehensive study must be undertaken especially in ICCA areas as the inventory in most sites were limited to flora. However, conduct of such study should be approved by the IP community and the design should allow them to take greater responsibility or at least encourage active participation.
In addition, there are 133 species (10 amphibia, 14 reptilia, 82 aves, 21 mamalia, 6 magnoliopsida) considered as least concern.
In Mt. Nacolod BD assessment, 2 new species of frogs were discovered, and 5 species (2 amphibia and 3 mamalia) were considered new island record.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Management Effectiveness in PAs and new conservation areas

baseline.comment: Average of 35 in all nine sites

target.comment:
Increase in METT scores in pilot sites by an average of at least 20% compared to baseline levels
METT scorecard applied in all PAs and new CAs as basis for supporting capacity development and implementing adaptive management

actual.comment:
Achieved. Average METT Scores of NewCAPP sites increased by 31 points or 83% from the average baseline score of 37.
Overall, the increase in the METT scores can be attributed to the generation of information in the process of establishing LCA and documentation and recognition of ICCA. These information improved the planning process and identification, and provided bases for issuing local resolutions for the establishment/recognition of conservation areas. There was also improvement in the monitoring system. Also, in general, there was improvement in the condition of the important values in the CA. Lastly, the community is slowly reaping economic benefits.
At the systemic level, BMB is routinely applying METT scorecard in all PAs.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Financing of national PA system, including new conservation areas

baseline.comment:
Governance frameworks for sustainable PA financing 33.3%
Business planning and other tools 19.6%
Tools and systems for revenue generation and mobilization 17.54%
TOTAL - 24.48%

target.comment:
Governance frameworks 79%
Business planning and other tools 57%
Tools and systems for revenue generation and mobilization 56%
TOTAL - 65%

actual.comment:
Partially Achieved.
Governance framework for sustainable PA financing 52%
Business planning and other tools 46%
Tools and systems for revenue generation and mobilization 38%
TOTAL 46%
While the Project was not able to meet the end of target level, there has been improvement in PA Financing scores in all aspects by a total of 21 percentage points compared to the baseline. While the Project has accomplished all outputs under Outcome 3, more needs to be done to improve capacity for system wide financing such as formulation and implementation of PA Business Plan. The results of the PA Financing Study has been translated into a Guide. However, BMB has to roll this out to the rest of the PAs. These requirements are being put together under the PA System Master Plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Capacity to manage national PA system

baseline.comment:
Systemic 43%
Institutional 47%
Individual 43%

target.comment:
Systemic 82%
Insitutional 73%
Individual 71%

actual.comment:
Partially Achieved.
Systemic 73%
Institutional 78%
Individual 86%
TOTAL - 81%
There has been an overall improvement in capacities, as evidenced by 35 percentage points increase over the baseline. The total score has surpassed the target, except for slight shortfalls in systemic capacities. These are in the areas of: (i) formulation of policies and plans; and (ii) engaging and building consensus. Please see below.

target.comment: Program for accelerated expansion of terrestrial PA system to include new conservation areas within KBAs developed and ready for implementation

actual.comment: TO BE DELETED.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: PA system of the Philippines has been expanded under new and diverse management regimes (ancestral domain, local government and community managed areas) to cover an additional 400,000 hectares of Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) and with enhanced potential for further expansion

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: Coverage of the national PA system in terms of governance types

baseline.comment: Limited to PAs established through the NIPAS process, managed by PAMBs only

target.comment: Coverage of national PA system is expanded to include new conservation areas under diverse governance types (IP, LGU and local community managed areas)

actual.comment:
Achieved. The Project has established two new modalities (LCA and ICCA) for expanding and diversifying the national protected area system. The BMB has adopted these and are being mainstreamed into the National PA System Master Plan. A Bill on ICCA was approved at the Committee level in both Houses of Congress. An Omnibus Bill that intends to legislate 97 PAs is also filed in Congress. It includes provisions on recognition of ICCA. As transitory mechanism, BMB Technical Bulletins on ICCA and LCA were prepared and undergoing final review. These specify the applicable policies to support requests for ICCA recognition and LCA establishment; and encourage field offices to provide support.
At the site level, a total of 148,342 hectares were designated as conservation areas. For ICCA, three sites (Mt. Kalatungan (http://www.iccaregistry.org/en/sites/27). Ayta Abellen tribe in Cabangan, Zambales (http://www.iccaregistry.org/en/sites/28); and Hilong hilong (http://www.iccaregistry.org/en/sites/31) have completed the entire process of documentation and are now registered at UNEP-WCMC ICCA Registry . Two additional sites - Banao tribe in BBNP Kalinga Watershed and Buhid and Bangon tribes in Mts. Iglit Baco KBA have both submitted their ICCA documentation and in the process of providing the additional information requested by UNEP-WCMC. The Balatoc tribe in Kalinga Watershed is in the final stages of the documentation and recognition process. By the end of the year, it is expected that an additional 11,000 hectares of ICCA will be included in the ICCA registry. The Dumagat Remontados in Mt. Irid Angelo KBA has yet to conduct resource inventory in the identified ICCA sites to enrich available information. Once completed, the ICCA case study will be prepared and submitted to UNEP-WCMC. However, community declaration of ICCA has been completed and its CCP and ICCA have been integrated in the ADSDPP of Dumagat Remontado, which was prepared in parallel with the ICCA documentation. For Ayta Abellen tribe in San Felipe, Zambales, the implementation was put on hold since 2014 due to internal conflicts among IP leaders within the tribe. IKSP documentation on resource management and governance, resource inventory, CCP have been completed. However, the CCP needs to be validated and the case study has to be prepared.
For LCA sites, the management plans were completed, LGU funding for initial implementation have been allocated, and all sites have secured policies to formalize the establishment of LCAs. Mangatarem and Mt. Tapulao, both in Zambales KBA, have established LCAs as critical habitats. Mangatarem has submitted their critical habitat management plans to the Office of the DENR Secretary for the issuance of Department Order. Mt. Tapulao is packaging the plan for submission also to DENR. Both LGUs have issued resolutions adopting the LCA. In Polillo Group of Islands, a total of 10,329 hectares of conservation area were strengthened/established under the Project. A draft PGI Biodiversity Conservation Strategic Action Plan was prepared in 2012 to support LCA. The three municipalities (Alcoy, Argao, and Dalaguete) covering Mts. Nug as and Lantoy KBA have agreed to establish the Nug as Palinpinon Biodiversity Corridor with a total area of 9,649 hectares. Each LGU has prepared and adopted a management plan. In Mt. Nacolod in Southern Leyte, the LCA Management Framework was adopted by the Provincial LGU through a Resolution. This Framework was turned over to the PLGU last June 29, 2015 during the environmental submit organized by the provincial government. It has 40,860 hectares within 7 municipalities in So. Leyte and Leyte. The PLGU also issued a resolution declaring Mt. Nacolod as Forest Protected Area in 2012. In Bud Bongao in Tawi Tawi, a Provincial Ordinance declaring 325 hectares of Bud Bongao Peak was issued in 2013. A Management Plan was also prepared and budget has been allocated for its implementation.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: Extent of the national terrestrial PA system in proportion to total area of the country

actual.comment: Achieved. 0.1 percent or 3,007,009 hectares. This represents an additional of 400,724 hectares from the baseline of 2.6 million hectares. The target was to increase the coverage of the protected area within KBAs to 3 million hectares or 10% of the total area of the country. NewCAPP contributed 148,342 hectares or 37% of the additional areas established over the course of the Project.During the Project, another PA outside of KBA was established covering 26,125 hectares - Upper Marikina River Basin Protected Landscape-under Proclamation Number 296 signed on November 24, 2012.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Representation of KBAs in biogeographic zones and ecosystem types in the national PA system

baseline.comment:
Greater Luzon BZ 48%
Mindoro BZ 49%
Greater Negros Panay BZ 47%
Greater Mindanao BZ 32%
Sulu BZ 29%

target.comment:
Greater Luzon BZ 56%
Mindoro BZ 81%
Greater Negros Panay BZ 50%
Greater Mindanao BZ 37%
Sulu BZ 46%

actual.comment:
Partially Achieved. At the time of design, it was thought that the Project will be able to place the entire KBA landscape under new conservation status. However, the reality is, KBAs comprise expansive landscapes which include patches of alienable and disposable lands, cultivated agriculture, forest plantations, and other land uses. Thus, the identification of new conservation areas was guided by BD assessments to determine the extent and location of areas that should be conserved; negotiations with local partners and stakeholders to engender ownership and support. As a result, the areas placed under conservation status (LCAs and ICCAs) represent only a portion (37%) of the total area of pilot KBAs of NewCAPP.
Greater Luzon BZ 53.02%. An additional 23 protected areas (15 LCAs; and 8 ICCAs) established/recognized since project start with a total of 99,939 hectares.
Mindoro BZ 58.22%. With the recognition of 3 ICCAs of the Buhid and BangonTribes in Mts. Iglit Baco KBA and 1 ICCA of the Mangyan Tagabukid, the total coverage of protected area under protection increased to 136,224 hectares against 233,590 hectares of KBA.
Greater Negros Panay BZ 49.52%. 3 LCAs comprising the Nugas Lantoy BD Corridor was established under the Project. The total area designated for conservation is 9,649 hectares bringing the total coverage to 167,929 hectares
Greater Mindanao BZ 38.52%. A total of 133,135 hectares were established from the proclamation of 2 PAs, establishment of 7LCAs, and recognition of 5 ICCA; thereby increasing the coverage to 1,023,897 hectares.
Sulu BZ 29.49%. The Project was able to establish 1 LCA in Bud Bongao; contributing 325 hectares to the 9,421 hectares baseline.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Program for expansion and diversification of national PA system

baseline.comment: None

target.comment: Expansion and diversification of the national PA system is guided by a 5 year program

actual.comment:
Achieved. Further expansion and diversification of the national PA system shall be guided by the Master Plan, which is an ongoing effort supported by various projects/donors. The Plan recognizes LCAs, ICCAs and OECMs as part of the national PA system.
The National Program Framework for ICCAs is contained in the Manila Declaration, which was produced from the First National ICCA Consortium in 2012.
Following the Declaration, the Project supported the establishment of the Philippine ICCA Consortium. Founded in February 2013, the Consortium adopted the name Bukluran ng mga Katutubo para sa Pangangalaga ng Kalikasan sa Pilipinas (BUKLURAN). While still in its nascent stage, it is actively participating in the discussions on ICCA at the national level:
With the BUKLURAN, the Project coordinated with the Office of Cong. Baguilat in the development of the ICCA Bill. It was passed at the Committee level of the House of Representatives in December 2014. A counterpart bill was filed by Sen. Loran Legarda in the Senate in February 2015, and was passed also at the Committee level in March 2015.
NewCAPP provided technical assistance to BMB and UNDP-Philippines in the formulation of a new project on ICCA with the BUKLURAN, UNDP, NCIP, PAFID and KASAPI. The project document was completed and submitted to GEF headquarters in May 2015.
In October 2014, the BMB-NewCAPP, in partnership with NCIP, BUKLURAN and many organizations, organized the 2nd National Conference on ICCA to assess progress of ICCA institutionalization in the country and implementation of the Manila Declaration (output of the first national conference). The Conference became a venue to share best practices and the support to ICCA was solidified. Different organizations from the government, private sector, and non-government organization committed to support the strengthening of ICCA in the country. It was also used to enhance the ADSDPP Guidelines and include the identification and documentation of ICCAs. This will usher a systemic and more systematic process. Along with BMB, the Conference was co-funded by PTFCF, GIZ, and UNDP-Philippines.
With enough lessons and experience on the ground on establishing local conservation area, the Project together with several organizations also conducted the First National Conference on LCA. Around 250 individuals from the LGUs, NGAs, NGOs, academe, private sector, and development organizations attended the conference. The Conference was able to consolidate support from all sectors on LCA and have increased buy in from DILG, HLURB and local chief executives. During the Conference, a Resolution was issued by the participants urging national government agencies to strengthen support to LGUs, and upscale the establishment of LCAs. This Resolution will be incorporated in the PA System Master Plan being developed.
Guides on the documentation and recognition of ICCA and establishment of LCA were finalized. The LCA Guide was launched with DILG and HLURB in 2015. The ICCA Sourcebook is for printing after incorporating comments from Global ICCA Consortium.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: Management effectiveness at nine pilot sites

baseline.comment:
BBNP 64
ZMR 18
Mts. IglitBaco 60
Mt.Irid Angelo and Binuang 21
Mt.Nug as Lantoy 51
Mt.Hilonghilong 15
Mt.Nacolod 10
Tawitawi 27
Polilio islands 47

target.comment:
BBNP 93
ZMR 79
Mts. IglitBaco 87
Mt.Irid Angelo and Binuang 76
Mt.Nug as Lantoy 95
Mt.Hilonghilong 79
Mt.Nacolod 78
Tawitawi 74
Polilio islands 90

actual.comment:
Partially Achieved.
- BBNP 73
- ZMR 65 -
- Mts. Iglit Baco 67
- Mt. Irid Angelo and Binuang 60
- Mt. Nug as Lantoy 81
- Mt. Hilonghilong 55 -
- Mt. Nacolod 69
- Tawitawi 64 -
- Polillo islands 71
While the Project met the target at the objective level overwhelmingly, none of the individual targets at the site level were met; as these targets were set quite high. For example in Mt. Nacolod, the baseline score was 10 and the end of project target was set to 78; this represents 680% increase. However, overall, there is significant increase in the scores across all sites.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: Incorporation of BD conservation goals in local plans

baseline.comment: Isolated efforts only by a few PAMBs and NGO partners

target.comment:
ADSDPP 4 (BBNP, ZMR, Mts. Iglit Baco, Mts. Irid Angelo and Binuang)
Resource management plans of local communities - 2 (Nug as Lantoy, Hilong hilong)
LGU land use and development plans 3 (Tawi tawi, Mt. Nacolod, and Polilio islands)

actual.comment:
Achieved.
In BBNP, the ICCAs of the Banao IP community has been declared by the LGU of Balbalan as conservation areas in the updating of their CLUP.
In the case of Balatoc IP community, the CCP is being prepared following completion of the resource inventory.
In the Zambales Mountain Range: The Critical Habitat Management Plan of Mangatarem LGU has been adopted by the Council, and endorsed to DENR for confirmation. The Plan was developed to be consistent with the Forest Land Use Plan (FLUP) of the municipality.
The Critical Habitat Management Plan of Palauig LGU for Mt. Tapulao has been completed and adopted by the Council. The Plan includes the entire forest land of the municipality and therefore also represent the FLUP.
The ICCA and CCP of Aeta Abellen in Maporac, Zambales has been incorporated in the updated ADSDPP of the IP community.
The ICCA documentation of Aeta IP community in San Felipe Zambales Mountain Range has been completed, and the CCP is up for validation by the community.
In Mt. Iglit Baco PA, the CCP of the Buhid Bangon Mangyan IP community has been completed and incorporated in the updated ADSDPP. The PA Management Plan for the Iglit Baco is due for development, where the ICCA and CCP will form an integral part.
In Mt. Irid Angelo, the ICCA documentation and its CCP are incorporated in the ADSDPP of the Dumagat Remontados IP community.
The LGUs of Argao, Alcoy and Dalaguete have each prepared their LCA Management Plan consistent with the goals and objectives of the Nug as Palinpinon Corridor. In Argao, the LCA Management Plan is also incorporated in the enhanced Forest Land Use Plan (FLUP). In Alcoy and Dalaguete, the FLUP has been prepared prior to NewCAPP, but it was ensured that the LCA Plan is consistent with their FLUPs. In each of these LGUs, the Municipal Councils have issued Resolutions adopting the LCA Management Plan.
In Mt. Hilong hilong, the CCP has been incorporated in the ADSDPP of the Mamanwa-Manobo IP community.
In Tawi-tawi, the LCA management plan was adopted by the LGU and budget for its implementation was integrated in the 2015 Annual Investment Plan of the LGU.
In Mt. Nacolod, the LCA Management Framework was prepared and adopted by the seven (7) Municipal LGUs and Provincial Council.
In the Polillo Group of Islands, the municipalities of Polillo, Burdeos and Panukulan who are among the first municipalities to establish LCAs have already integrated the LCA Management Plans in their CLUPs and are already updating their plans at present.
In the case of Mt. Kalatungan, the ICCA and CCP have been adopted by the Protected Area Management Board (PAMB). The updated PA Management Plan of Mt. Kalatungan Natural Park dedicates a section on management of ancestral domains within the PA.

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description: Operational Manual for local management bodies

baseline.comment: Inadequate for use by existing PAMBs; no Manual yet for local management bodies of new conservation areas

target.comment: Operational Manuals are implemented to strengthen capacities of local management bodies of existing PAs and new conservation areas

actual.comment:
Achieved.
The Handbook for PAMB Operations and the accompanying training modules has been submitted and is now undergoing final review. The BMB will take on the roll out of the manual and training modules once finalized .

indicator.title: Indicator 10
indicator.description: Capacities for M and E

baseline.comment: Weak for existing PAs; no M and E protocols for new conservation areas

target.comment: PAWB and local PA/CA Managers and staff have capacities to undertake M and E and use this information for adaptive management

actual.comment:
Achieved.
NewCAPP carried out a review of implementation of BMS in August 2013 which identified a set of recommendations for improvement. These were taken on by the Wildlife Resources Division. In addition, the GIZ-PAME is supporting the development of cost effective BD baseline and monitoring methods that consider the recommendation of the earlier NewCAPP study and the competency standards for PA sector.
NIPAS PA M and E system drafted. A discussion with BMB Senior Staff and other FAPs was held to review the NIPAS Program and the revised NIPAS M and E indicators and reference sheets. These will be integrated in the M and E System of the PA System Master Plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 11
indicator.description: Awareness and support from stakeholders for national PA system

actual.comment:
Achieved.
Proposed Legislations. The proposed PA Omnibus Bill will strengthen the legal status of 97 proclaimed PAs, into full gazzetted PAs, covering 2.6 Million hectares and 179,439 hectares of buffer zones. The Enhanced NIPAS Bill also contains a provision recognizing ICCAs within PAs. Congressman Baguilat also filed an ICCA Bill in Congress, followed by Senator Legarda at the Senate. The bill was approved by the Committee level. Next step, coordinate with the Committee Secretariat for the Plenary Discussion/s.
Funding Support from Various Sources. Since NewCAPP started in 2009, additional projects were implemented in the sector, with an estimated total funding commitment of USD 51.9 M. These are:
UNDP-GEF-BPP (USD 4.5 M)
GIZ-PAME (USD 9.9M)
USAID-B+WISER (USD 25 M)
UNDP-GEF-MKBA (USD 8 M)
UNDP-GEF-SGP (USD 4.5M)
Legislative Support. With ASoG, a briefing with Congress on the Second State of the PA Report was held on October 28, 2014. Those who attended the presentation expressed support to additional funding and the passage of the Omnibus Bill on PAs.
Reduction in Levels of Destructive Activities. The LCA Management Plans and ICCA/CCPs specify that there will be no destructive activities that will be allowed in these areas. EMB Memorandum Circular 005 dated July 2014 (Revised Guidelines for Coverage Screening and Standardized Requirements under the Philippines EIS System) has categorized LCAs and ancestral domains as environmentally critical areas.
In Mt. Hilong-hilong, the MGB representative requested a copy of the shape files of the ICCA site to designate it as no go zone for mining.
Number of proposed development projects rejected for being incompatible with PA and CA management objectives. 11 of NewCAPP sites have clearly stated in their management/conservation plans the prohibition of extractive/destructive activities within the conservation areas such mining. LGUs have likewise issued support policies such as:
-Polillo SB Resolutions nos. 119 2012, 069-2011 reiterated their strong opposition to mining and quarrying operations and similar activities within their jurisdiction.
-Mt. Nacolod the Provincial Board issued Resolution No. 740-s.2012 which disallows any form of mining activity in the LCA.
-In BBNP, the strength and unity of the tribe and community prevented the operation of CelloPhil and saved the forest. CelloPhil established pulp and paper processing plant in the 70s threatening the lush forests of BBNP. The main reason behind the resistance was the Bodong or traditional resources management in the area. Since then, no extractive activity has threatened the area. The Bodong and Lapat highlighted the ICCA and CCP of the Banao and Balatoc Tribe.
Nug as Palinpinon - In 2013, there was an incident of clearing in some parts of the Argao forests by the LGU for tourism purposes. However, this was immediately arrested upon the knowledge of the DENR Regional Office of Region 7 and a case was already filed in court to address the incident.
IEC Support for the 2 National Conferences. Case stories from NewCAPP sites prepared and distributed during the First National LCA Conference and Second National ICCA Conference held in October 2014. New exhibit panels on ICCA and LCA were prepared and launched during the conferences.
PMU also supported DENR Region 10 in the development of IEC materials for its 1st Protected Area Conference on July 22-23, 2014.
The NewCAPP website has been continuously updated with latest project activities and technical/project reports. From October 2011-June 2015, the average website daily hits is 1,237; the monthly average is 37,381. Since the website was established in October 2011, it has generated a total of 1.68 million hits by the end of June 2015.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Enhanced financial sustainability of the terrestrial PA system

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: National level capacity to manage financing of the PA system

baseline.comment: Limited capacity by PAWB to manage financing for national PA system

target.comment: PAWB has improved capacity to use new tools and mechanisms to sustainably manage financing of national terrestrial PA system to include new CAs

actual.comment:
Achieved.
Draft Addendum to DENR Administratve Order No. 2007-17 on the Rules and Regulations Governing Special Uses within Protected Areas (SAPA). NewCAPP commissioned a study on SAPA fees being collected in PAs in 2011 to establish a common methodology in computing SAPA fees across all PAs. A recommendation to increase fees from SAPA using market values of properties, thereby potentially increasing internally generated revenues across all PAs was presented and discussed with PAWB and DENR Undersecretary. These recommendations were translated into a draft Addendum to the existing Department Administrative Order (DAO) for the following objectives:
? To provide premium to ecosystem services provided by PAs, e.g., water production, which are limited resources;
? To generate revenues which can be utilized for improved management and operations of the protected area; thereby decreasing required national government subsidy;
? To serve as a regulatory tool or disincentive for increased resource uses beyond the carrying-capacities of PAs; and
? To increase local economic opportunities, e.g., increased local employment from eco-tourism establishments.
Recommendations for maximizing the potentials offered by existing financing instruments. A review of Department Administrative Order 2000-51 or the policy on PA user fees was undertaken to conduct an inventory of user fees being collected in three PAs, namely Mt. Apo Natural Park, Mt. Kanlaon Natural Park and Mt. Kitanglad Natural Park; constraints on not being able to maximize potentials of user fees; and recommendations on improving PA financing. The study recommended (i) improvement in implementation of DAO 2000-51 and (ii) promotion of other sustainable financing mechanisms.
Increased understanding of Integrated Protected Area Fund (IPAF) management and disbursment process of PA staff. A review of IPAF collections, procedures, and status of all 240 PAs was undertaken by the Project. A Technical Brief was prepared summarizing the findings and disseminated to DENR audiences, and other stakeholders. A total of 120 PAs from 200 participants attended the training in 2012; while 353 participants from 131 PAs attended the IPAF training in 2015.
Defined procedures and accountability centers in implementation of RA 10629. NewCAPP provided technical assistance to BMB in developing the implementing guidelines of Republic Act 10629 or An Act Providing for the Retention by PAMB of 75% of Revenues accruing to IPAF, Amending for the Purpose Section 16 of RA 7586 known as NIPAS Act of 1992. Signed in September 26, 2013, RA 10629 provides for retention of 75% of PA income at PAMB level. To set operational procedures on how RA 10629 would have to be implemented by PAs, NewCAPP assisted BMB in working with DBM-Bureau E and BTr-NCAD in crafting the DENR-DBM Joint Memorandum Circular (JMC) 2014-1 which was signed in September 26, 2014 by Secretary Paje of DENR, Secretary Abad of DBM, with Congressman Teves as key witness.
Improved collaboration among donor-funded Projects providing technical assistance to the Bureau on financing. NewCAPP convened the PA Financing FAPs Thematic Group where an agreement is reached to work together on PA Financing Roadmap. The National PA Financing Roadmap which intends to provide overall direction and strategy for sustaining financing of PAs and other conservation areas was included in the PA System Master Plan component.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: PA Financial Sustainability, as measured by Financing scorecard

baseline.comment:
Legal and regulatory framework 33.3%
Business planning 19.6%
Tools for revenue generation 17.54%
Total 24.48%

target.comment:
Legal and regulatory framework 79%
Business planning 57%
Tools for revenue generation 56%
Total 65%

actual.comment:
Partially Achieved.
- Legal and regulatory framework 52%
- Business planning 46%
- Tools for revenue generation 56%
- Total 46%
While the target scores were not met, there has been improvement in PA Financing scores in all aspects by a total of 21 percentage points compared to the baseline. While the Project has accomplished all outputs under Outcome 3, more needs to be done to improve capacity for system wide financing such as formulation and implementation of PA Business Plan. The results of the PA Financing Study has been translated into a Guide. However, BMB has to roll this out to the rest of the PAs. These requirements are being put together under the PA System Master Plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: Number of sites with capacities for financing, business planning and cost effective management

baseline.comment: Nil

target.comment: At least 3 new PA/CAs have capacities for site level financing, business planning and cost effective management

actual.comment:
Achieved.
A PA business planning process was rolled-out in eighteen selected PAs through Sustainable Financing of Protected Areas Project of WB-GEF NSP-ENRMP. NewCAPP developed the Terms of Reference of this Project and heavily supported PAWB in the procurement process and implementation of the said Project. Following the business planning process introduced by REECS - the Projects contractor - NewCAPP documented the process and integrated it in the LCA Guide developed and published by the Project. The business planning module was also demonstrated in Mt. Nacolod in Southern Leyte and Mts. Nug-as and Lantoy in Cebu as part of the LCA management planning process.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: Number of PAs/CAs using new tools and mechanisms for sustainable financing

baseline.comment: Nil

target.comment: Additional PAs/CAs benefit from use of learning manual, revised policies, and replication of sustainable financing tools and mechanisms for PA/CA management

actual.comment:
Achieved.
18 PAs benefitted from technical assistance in the enhancement of management plans, preparation of Business Plans, and identification of specific financing mechanisms.
The two waves of IPAF trainings (2012 and 2015) benefitted 300 participants from 131 PAs through IPAF retention policies, and sharing of successful mechanisms to raise PA financing. The IPAF Handbook will benefit all PAs.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: Access to IPAF and levels of collection

baseline.comment:
IPAF annual allocations legislated through General Appropriations Act
US $ 2.98 Million

target.comment:
100% of IPAF collections automatically appropriated for PA management
Increase in IPAF collections by 25% or to a level of US $ 3.73 Million

actual.comment:
Achieved.
By virtue of Republic Act 10629, 75% of PA earnings are automatically retained within the PA to support implementation of its management plan.
As of March 2015, total IPAF collections = USD 7.79 Million. This represents an increase of 161%.
